Weâ€™ve all seen what source code looks like. But of course, usually, source code is just represented as this big flat string, just a sequence of characters. So, parsing is kind of the first step necessary for a computer to be able to do anything with your code. It starts with this big string and somehow, it has to figure out, what does this string mean and what am I supposed to do with it? Before it starts actually trying to do anything with it, the first thing it needs to do is just try and figure out what the structure of the program is. Just figure out all of its component parts and basically it just converts it from a string into a data structure thatâ€™s easier to write code over, thatâ€™s easier for a program to deal with. Parsing is that process of taking a string that represents some sort of input format, some sort of language or format and turning it into a data structure. Language grammar is the other half of the title of the show. Thatâ€™s sort of a way of specifying the particular format of some syntax or another. Each language has its own format. And somehow, you need a way of saying, these are the possible things that you can say in this format and this is what theyâ€™re supposed to look like. So, grammar is a way of really precisely saying, this is exactly what the syntax looks like for this particular language. And then, it turns out that the two connect to each other because grammars are so nice and precise that it turns out you can build tools that automatically take one of those grammars and just spit out a parser for you automatically. So, you donâ€™t actually have to implement the parser by hand. Thereâ€™s many, many, many years of research that went into making that work. But thatâ€™s actually pretty stable research that was done back in, I think it started in the â€˜60â€™s. I think it really started getting stable in the â€˜70â€™s and by the â€˜80â€™s, it sort of seen as a pretty well-solved problem. So, grammars are this nice way of describing a syntax. Parsers are a nice way of recognizing a syntax and turning it into a data structure. And then, thereâ€™s these things called parser generators that can take a grammar and give you a parser. So, thatâ€™s just like saying what are legal strings into a programming language basically, right? So, what actually gives those meanings? DAVID:Â  Depending on who you ask. Once you get past the syntax and start talking about what the meaning or the behavior of programs are supposed to be. Iâ€™m not sure how much we actually want to get into that in this particular episode since weâ€™re talking about syntax. But semantics is kind of what happens after youâ€™ve got that data structure which is known as an Abstract Syntax Tree. Once youâ€™ve done the parsing, now the real fun begins because you actually have to do something with this data structure. And if youâ€™re talking about like a language interpreter, itâ€™s supposed to run the program. Or if youâ€™re talking about a compiler, itâ€™s supposed to translate that program to another language. Semantics is the way that we specify what the correct behavior is or what the correct translation would be for a compiler. And thereâ€™s a ton of different ways of specifying semantics. And thatâ€™s when kind of the real deep hairy language research kind of kicks in. CHUCK:Â  Weâ€™ve mentioned it a few times but can you explain what an Abstract Syntax Tree actually is? DAVID:Â  An Abstract Syntax Tree is that data structure that spits out the other end of a parser. So, itâ€™s known as abstract because you can think of the actual syntax thatâ€™s in the string as being the concrete syntax for the language. Thatâ€™s really what it looks like to us as people, as humans. But the computer doesnâ€™t really care. Did you spell function, F-U-N-C-T-I-O-N or did you spell it F-U-N or did you spell it Lambda? Different languages have different ways of spelling these things. But you can think of those as just kind of skins, the sort of the user interface for the programmers. And humans are the only ones who really care about that. But abstractly, underneath, you just sort of have this data structure that says, â€œWell, this is a function and itâ€™s got so many arguments and itâ€™s got a body,â€ and stuff like that. But once youâ€™re down at that data structure, you donâ€™t really care how specifically it was spelled in the string. ARIYA:Â  The easiest way to understand the Abstract Syntax Tree of a JavaScript code is by using the Esprima: Parser demo. So, I build this and it shows exactly the tree of your code. CHUCK:Â  And SpiderMonkey is the JavaScript engine for Mozilla? DAVID: Â  Thatâ€™s right. Itâ€™s the one that ships in Firefox. Like basically, what it does is it runs the internal parser but then it takes the internal C++ data structure that would be unsafe and copies it into a safe JavaScript object. That was a difficult process. MERRICK:Â  So, can you guys explain? You touched a bit on the parser piece and I usually hear another word when that comes along which is Lexer. Does Lexer typically come before parser and you guys touch on what that is? DAVID:Â  Yeah. I have an answer to that. So, most programming languages will typically divide up this process that goes from the source string into an AST, into kind of two parts. And like you said, the first one is the Lexer. The Lexer is kind of like a mini parser. Itâ€™s doing less work than the parser is, but what itâ€™s doing is itâ€™s taking the string of characters and actually recognizing kind of little component chunks. You can think of it as, an analogy in human language, you can think of it as the thing that tells you what the words are, and then the parser tells you how the words come together to build sentences. So, the Lexer is going to say things like you wrote obj.foo, thatâ€™s really three, what they call tokens, or you can think of it sort of like words. The first one is OBJ which is an identifier, the second one is dot which is a special symbol in JavaScript that has a special meaning by itself, and then the third one is another identifier, Foo. So, the Lexer is just going to say, â€œI have three tokens. I see three tokens here, OBJ, Dot, and Foo.â€ And then, the parser is going to say, â€œI have identifier, dot, identifier,â€ that actually represents a property selection for my object. And so, it will build an AST node, an Abstract Syntax Tree node that represents that structure. Itâ€™s actually possible for some languages not to have a Lexer but itâ€™s rare. Usually, thatâ€™s a good way to divide up the work. CHUCK:Â  So, letâ€™s say that I want to write my own language, and Iâ€™m going to be real creative and Iâ€™m going to call it blavascript and anywayâ€¦ [Laughter] JAMISON:Â  From Transylvania. ARIYA: Â The classic example in JavaScript is a forward slash because it can start a regular expression. But in some cases, itâ€™s actually an operator. TIM:Â  Yeah, thatâ€™s a fun one. And CoffeeScript is one of those harder ones. So, when youâ€™re designing your language, if you have the freedom to design the syntax, if you want to make your life easy on you, design a syntax thatâ€™s not ambiguous. But those arenâ€™t always the easier to use languages. ARIYA:Â  Indeed. DAVID:Â  So, this is one of the classic tradeoffs when youâ€™re trying to -- so, it kind of gets back to, I think it was Charles who asked the question. If I wanted to design my own language, how would I go about coming up with a syntax and coming up with a parser? Thatâ€™s actually a really subtle design question. And one of the tradeoffs that Tim is getting at is you can sort of design the grammar of the language to be simpler for algorithms to parse. Or you could design it so that itâ€™s sort of more pleasant for humans to look at and easier for them to read. And it turns out that humans are a lot messier than computers. So, our tastes often run in directions that go completely at odds with what algorithms would really like to see. And so, overloading is a great example of where -- humans are really comfortable with brackets meaning different things in different contexts, but that makes the algorithm much trickier because now, it has to use additional contextual information to figure out exactly what itâ€™s looking at in various points. And so, some languages have really gone sort of hog wild with context sensitivity. One of the great examples is the C programming languages where you canâ€™t even tell what basic kind of token youâ€™re looking at without knowing the full scope of the program and all of the type definitions in the program basically due to really fiddly details in the way they design the grammar. So, it has tradeoffs, like on the one hand, people like looking at the C syntax and they find that ambiguity not a problem for themselves and it reads nicely for them. On the other hand, because itâ€™s so much harder to write the tools, itâ€™s actually pretty uncommon for people to go and write a new C parser because itâ€™s so incredibly hard to write a C parser. On top of that, all of these parser generators we were talking about which can take a grammar and automatically spit out a parser so you donâ€™t have to write it by hand, itâ€™s pretty much impossible for any of them to generate a C parser automatically. So, you end up having to write it by hand. So in practice, all of the C parsers are handwritten. Pretty similar with JavaScript because of that ambiguity with the slash character, itâ€™s pretty hard to use a parser generator to automatically give you a JavaScript parser. So, people end up having to write it by hand which means that it takes really smart people like Ariya to actually build a JavaScript parser and they donâ€™t come by everyday. So, itâ€™s a tough tradeoff. CHUCK:Â  So this leads me to two things. First off, you said that humans are messier than computers. And I have four kids and three computers and I have to agree. [Laughter] CHUCK:Â  The second thing is that, is it an all or nothing proposition to use a parser generator? Or can you use it to get you most of the way there and then kind of deal with the ambiguities on a one by one basis? TIM:Â  So, thatâ€™s what I was about to talk about with CoffeeScript, you canâ€™t actually do the grammar using Jison which is the parser generator we use, because itâ€™s just not possible. So Jeremyâ€™s idea was he added a layer between the Lexer and the parser that rearranges the tokens, that gets rid of the ambiguities. Kind of massages it manually. ARIYA:Â  That was also my first approach to build a JavaScript parser in JavaScript meaning using hybrid approach. Some parser is generated by some parser generator and then I tried to work around some problem by manually writing some code. But it turns out with JavaScript, you end up writing so much code that it doesnâ€™t really make sense to keep the generator proper from the parser generator anymore. And thatâ€™s how Iâ€™d done it with Esprima. So in some cases, if you describe a grammar for say, a while statement, the grammar for the while statement looks pretty clear. And if you go through the code, sometimes the code is messier. But at some point, you realize that just by looking at how while statement parsing is implemented, itâ€™s not much more difficult. And therefore, you just dump the grammar and thereâ€™s no need to feed the parser generator to generate the parser anymore because if you code it carefully, the parser code is obvious, is understandable enough. I donâ€™t know if I make sense there. MERRICK:Â  Yeah, it makes sense. DAVID:Â  Basically, what youâ€™re saying is that because the grammar is a pretty clear specification, itâ€™s not that hard to just follow it by hand and just write the code yourself. ARIYA:Â  Right. DAVID:Â  And another thing is people often find that when they write it themselves, they can start to hand optimize it. And parsers tend to be one of those things where it doesnâ€™t change very often because you donâ€™t change the syntax. So, once you kind of get it working, then you can go and start optimizing it to try to get better performance out of it and not have to worry about your optimizations needing to be undone in the future because youâ€™re not going to be changing the syntax anyway. So, when you have production quality JavaScript parsers, for example, there were some, I believe historically, in the production JavaScript engines that use parser generators originally. But then, as performance became more and more competitive in JavaScript engines, they pretty much all ended up handwriting their parsers so that they could hand optimize them. ARIYA:Â  An example would be JavaScriptCore, which is the JavaScript engine in WebKit. It was originally derived from KGS, from KGE. And KGS grammar is described for Bison, I believe. And then it is generated to C and then we have to bind it to C++. So, thereâ€™s a whole bunch of layers there and you still need to implement some native C++ code to work around some parsing problems. Semicolon for example; automatic semicolon insertion that requires work around almost everywhere. It just doesnâ€™t make sense to keep the old generated code. CHUCK:Â  So, that kind of leads into the next question and that is the specification changes for JavaScript. Some of these is just, youâ€™re essentially adding new tokens or adding new functions to your list of things that JavaScript can do. And in some cases, like the semicolon injection stuff, it kind of touches everything. So, what are the tradeoffs? I mean, if you have a parser that youâ€™ve been able to just generate and then they introduce some kind of breaking change, are you back to square one or square zero? DAVID:Â  Well, the bottom line, like the number one ground rule is youâ€™re not allowed to make breaking changes except in extremely corner cases where you think no code will actually be affected by it. This is one of the really tricky things about migrating a syntax or evolving a syntax is itâ€™s really easy to accidentally add something that breaks the rest of the language. It could either break backwards compatibility or it could introduce an ambiguity where there might be two possible ways to understand some piece of syntax. And thatâ€™s one of the worst kinds of bugs when youâ€™re designing a syntax because now, itâ€™s totally unclear what the behavior of the program should be because the syntax could actually mean two totally separate things. So, one of the nice things about parser generators is even if you donâ€™t use them in production, if you run a grammar through a parser generator and it succeeds at providing you with a parser on the other end, unless itâ€™s some strange esoteric parser generator that can handle ambiguous grammars which those are rare. Most parser generators will fail if thereâ€™s an ambiguity. Thatâ€™s actually a way to tell, â€œOkay, we definitely have an unambiguous grammar.â€ Thereâ€™s no possible string of characters that could be interpreted in two contradictory ways. But itâ€™s really surprisingly tricky. And ASI is one of the worse ones. Automatic semi colon insertion is one of the worse ones. Actually, itâ€™s probably a good moment for a public service announcement. When you design your next programming language, please donâ€™t use Automatic Semicolon Insertion. Itâ€™s just more trouble than itâ€™s worth. [Laughter] JAMISON:Â  Donâ€™t worry, Iâ€™m not. DAVID:Â  Itâ€™s going to lead to a really difficult language to parse. But on top of that, itâ€™s going to lead to endless Twitter wars between people arguing about whether they should use it or not. So, just donâ€™t bother. [Crosstalk] TIM:Â  I think Go-lang has that but youâ€™re not supposed to put them in your actual written code. It just adds them for you when it compiles. I could be wrong about this. Iâ€™m not an expert at Go. But from what I understand, they actually have some similar kind of hazards to JavaScript where -- like in JavaScript, if you see a return and then an expression but you put a new line in between them, famous hazard. Where you think thatâ€™s a return with an argument but it actually gets a semicolon inserted. I think in Go -- people will have to correct me after the show if I got this wrong. But if you do like a function call where the function returns another function and you want to call that again. So like F(), if you put that second pair of parenâ€™s in the next line, I think it actually inserts a semicolon between them. So, thatâ€™s different from JavaScript which doesnâ€™t insert a semicolon. But that sort of a similar hazard. So, in my opinion, semicolon insertion ends up being kind of too hazardous. I think you can introduce syntaxes where theyâ€™re not based on semicolons but there are these kinds of ambiguities. Itâ€™s not exactly an ambiguity but itâ€™s just a human confusion, an easy confusion for humans. But doing it through automatic insertion of semicolons just seems like itâ€™s always more trouble than itâ€™s worth. [Crosstalk] ARIYA:Â  I can't always figure out the automatic semicolon insertion rules. So, I always joke around that itâ€™s called semi-automatic semicolon insertion. [Laughter] DAVID:Â  Itâ€™s a semi-automatic weapon. CHUCK:Â  Thatâ€™s right. You can pull the trigger as many times as you want and it will keep shooting until youâ€™re out of bullets. [Laughter] ARIYA:Â  What do you think itâ€™s doing? Talking about syntax change again. For example, that syntax change that Dave mentioned that sometimes you donâ€™t need to tweak the syntax very much or you just pass it to the parser generator. But thereâ€™s also syntax change that will cause major disasters. For example, one of the nice things about C is that you cannot have nested functions. There cannot be functions inside of functions. So, if the next person with C language says, â€œLetâ€™s change syntax so you can have nested functions.â€ That will be just a nightmare. TIM:Â  What are some of the problems that itâ€™s going to cause for C syntactically? ARIYA:Â  Well, you need to understand and rewrite all the parsers again because those do not understand that yes, you can have a function inside a function. DAVID:Â  Oh! So, itâ€™s just going to be a lot of work to update all those processes? The worst case scenario is when you introduce something where it actually causes an ambiguity. And thatâ€™s the one where you might not even notice. And I've seen it happen where we tried to add syntaxes to the ECMAScript standard and it took a while for somebody to even notice, â€œOops! That introduces an ambiguity.â€ JAMISON:Â  Oh, thereâ€™s not a way that you can automatically detect that? DAVID:Â  That is one of those fun computer science questions that the general question of â€˜give me any grammar whatsoever and tell me if itâ€™s ambiguousâ€™ is actually mathematically impossible to build an algorithm that can give you that answer in finite time. JAMISON:Â  Does it give it a halting problem or something? DAVID:Â  Yeah, through a series of really complicated proof. But essentially it ends up being like -- I think it went through this classic problem called post correspondence problem or something. Iâ€™m forgetting it now but PCP was the shorthand for it. I think that was the way it was proved and then that can be reduced to the halting problem. Anyway, the long story short is, you canâ€™t write a general purpose algorithm for any grammar but for certain subclasses of grammars, you can. So, thatâ€™s why if you have a parser generator that works for a certain subclass of grammars and thereâ€™s all these different families that Tim eluded to earlier like thereâ€™s LL grammars, LR grammars, LALR grammars, and all these weird technical names for different sub-families of grammars. Each one of those, you actually can produce an algorithm that can prove whether a grammar is ambiguous or not. So typically, the real parser generators can actually do that for you because they only operate on these subsets. JAMISON:Â  So, how much of language design is limited by people trying, by the language designers trying to make their lives easier? Because I look at it totally from the outside, like I just wanted this feature and I have no idea what it takes or how much work it will be, itâ€™ll just be really cool. Does that happen a lot? Do you just reject things because theyâ€™ll be really hard to implement even if theyâ€™d be a cool or useful feature? TIM:Â  Iâ€™ve done that a few times with my new language Iâ€™m designing. And so, I just donâ€™t have a lot of feature in the language. One that Iâ€™ve been having trouble with lately is argument destructuring which is a really cool feature. But itâ€™s kind of tricky to do. DAVID:Â  Yeah. Weâ€™ve run into some of the things with the Rust Programming Language, where again, we were trying to keep it so that the syntax doesnâ€™t get too complicated so that itâ€™s easy to build tools for Rust. You have to remember when youâ€™re designing a language that you serve many, many different customers. And certainly, your self as the implementer is one customer. But simplicity of implementation also affects tool writers, and those tool writers may not be your self. And the easier you make things for tool writers, the easier you ultimately make things for developers because developers are going to use these tools too. So, even though there might be something that kind of has an immediate benefit for a developer because as a programming feature, itâ€™s nice, if it hurts the ability of tool writers to write tools, that could ultimately indirectly hurt developers, or in the longer run, hurt developers too. So, thereâ€™s a lot of constraints you have to keep in mind at the same time. On the other hand, I tend to still be willing to violate even my own ground rules that I set for my self. Like, okay, we want to make it easier for tool writers but, oh man! This syntax is just too nice. Weâ€™ll make an exception here and weâ€™ll make it a little harder for the tool writers. Theyâ€™ll still cope. Tool writers are smart people. Theyâ€™ll figure it out. JAMISON:Â  I guess itâ€™s like an opportunity cost, right? Like if the syntax is nice enough, then more people will use the language, then youâ€™ll have more tool writers and things like that. [Crosstalk] DAVID:Â  But youâ€™re also predicting what people are going to do in ten years, like when do we have a language that actually takes the world by storm? And a million people will write tools for it. Thatâ€™s so far into the future. Itâ€™s actually hard to predict what itâ€™s going to look like. CHUCK:Â  I want to go back to something that weâ€™ve kind of talked about but didnâ€™t really, we didnâ€™t talk about as far as what it actually means. So, we talked about kind of what a grammar is. But how is a grammar actually defined? DAVID:Â  Iâ€™m glad you asked this because this is something that I think is really a great general purpose tool for people to learn. And I think the analogy I want to make is for Regular Expressions. So, Regular Expressions are just this weird little language that people learn. And I mean, the first time you look at a Regular Expression you think, â€œOkay. Computer Science people have really lost their minds.â€ This is the weirdest, most arcane little thing Iâ€™ve ever seen. People talk about it as write once, read never. And it is a really weird little language but itâ€™s so powerful. And itâ€™s so concise that people use it constantly to the point where they just write little grunt command lines and do little one off Regex because theyâ€™re just so powerful. And so, itâ€™s actually worth it to put in that effort to learn Regular Expressions because itâ€™s so powerful. But it turns out the Regular Expressions are actually nowhere near as powerful as grammars are. Grammars are sort of the next step up in power for being able to describe a class of syntaxes. Regex and grammars are really doing the same basic thing. Theyâ€™re saying, â€œHereâ€™s what a particular syntax should look like.â€ Then you run a recognizer to actually parse it. The thing is that the class of syntaxes that a grammar can recognize is far, far more expressive than the class of things that a Regular Expression can. So, itâ€™s worth it to learn the notation on grammars because itâ€™s just so much more expressive. And then once you kind of learn that, you can use that for all sorts of things. For example, if you want to create a new configuration file format for your application, or you want to describe some network protocol where youâ€™re sending things encoded in strings over the Internet. Thereâ€™s all sorts of things where people need to describe a syntax format and Regex is not powerful enough to do the job. The other cool thing about grammars is that theyâ€™re still less powerful than just writing a regular program. And so, theyâ€™re sort of this nice sweet spot in between. So, the notation is known as BNF. It stands for Backus-Naur Form, named after two famous computer scientists. And so, taking the time to learn BNF I think is a really valuable skill for programmers to learn. JOE:Â  And how does one learn these [inaudible] secrets of which you speak? DAVID:Â  [Chuckles] Thatâ€™s a good question. I think a lot of BNF is covered in, I think probably most compiler textbooks will cover BNF. You can probably get a lot of material just from Googling it because itâ€™s such a common tool in Computer Science that thereâ€™s probably a ton of literature just online. The other thing is like to understand BNF, BNF itself is almost like a tiny little programming language. For the most part, itâ€™s a really simple little programming language. You basically define a bunch of functions and they can call each other. Thatâ€™s really all there is to it. The one hard thing thatâ€™s conceptually tricky that you need to get your head around before you get to that point is to be able to think recursively. And thatâ€™s a skill a lot of people donâ€™t have and arenâ€™t born with. It certainly took me a whole bunch of training before I felt comfortable with recursion. And BNF grammars are defined all using recursion. So for that, Iâ€™ll just throw out one textbook that I particularly love. Actually, I think Recursive Descent Parsers, even though the name sounds scary, are sort of like, to my mind, theyâ€™re the first way you would think to implement a parser. And they sort of follow the structure of the grammar most naturally. So, if your grammar says that an expression can be either a number or an expression followed by the plus sign, followed by an expression, then you write your Recursive Descent Parser that just says, â€œOkay, letâ€™s look at the token. DAVID:Â  So, Recursive Descent, kind of by itself, is, I think, the cleanest and most natural way to write a parser following the grammar that specifies what itâ€™s supposed to look like.
